questions.text: Ketone bodies can be utilized by all, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ketone bodies serve as an important fuel for most extrahepatic tissues during prolonged fasting or starvation.
  • However, RBCs (Red Blood Cells) cannot utilise ketone bodies because they lack mitochondria, which are essential for ketolysis.
  • Similarly, the liver, though the site of ketone body synthesis, cannot utilise them due to the absence of the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA: acetoacetate CoA transferase).
  • Thus, both RBCs and the liver are non-utilizers of ketone bodies, but the question asks for the only exception, making RBC the correct choice.

Explanation of other options:

Brain (Option B): The brain switches to ketone bodies as a major fuel source during prolonged fasting (>3 days).

Skeletal Muscle (Option C): Utilises ketone bodies early during fasting before switching to fatty acid oxidation.

Renal Cortex (Option D): Actively uses ketone bodies during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: Rothera's test is used for the detection of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rothera's test (Nitroprusside test) is a qualitative test used to detect ketone bodies (specifically acetone and acetoacetate) in urine.
  • The test is based on the reaction of ketone groups with sodium nitroprusside in an alkaline medium to produce a purple-colored complex.
  • Beta-hydroxybutyrate, however, is not detected as it lacks a free keto group.
  • Other confirmatory tests include Gerhardt's test (ferric chloride reaction for acetoacetate).

Explanation of other options:

Proteins (Option A): Detected by sulfosalicylic acid test or heat coagulation test.

Glucose (Option B): Detected by Benedict's test or glucose oxidase method.

Fatty Acid (Option C): Detected using chemical extraction and chromatography.

choices.text: Ketogenesis occurs when there is a high rate of fatty acid oxidation
Acetoacetate continually undergoes spontaneous oxidation to yield acetone
Acetone is a waste product which, as it is volatile, can be excreted via the lungs.
The liver produces considerable quantities of acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Ketone bodies except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketogenesis occurs when there is a high rate of fatty acid oxidation in the liver (Option A)
  • Under metabolic conditions associated with a high rate of fatty acid oxidation, the liver produces considerable quantities of acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate but does not utilise them due to the absence of thiophorase. (Option D)
  • Acetoacetate continually undergoes spontaneous decarboxylation to yield acetone, not oxidation.
  • These three substances are collectively known as the ketone bodies.
  • Acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are interconverted by the mitochondrial enzyme 3-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase; the equilibrium is controlled by the mitochondrial [NAD+]/[NADH] ratio, that is, the redox state.
  • The concentration of total ketone bodies in the blood of well-fed mammals does not normally exceed 2 mmol/L except in ruminants.
  • In vivo, the liver appears to be the only organ in non-ruminants to add significant quantities of ketone bodies to the blood.
  • Extrahepatic tissues utilise acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate as respiratory substrates.
  • Acetone is a waste product which, as it is volatile, can be excreted via the lungs (Option C)
  • Because there is active synthesis but little utilisation of ketone bodies in the liver, while they are used but not produced in extrahepatic tissues, there is a net flow of the compounds to the extrahepatic tissues.

questions.text: The immediate precursor in the formation of acetoacetate from acetyl-CoA in the liver is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HMG-CoA (3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA) is the immediate precursor of acetoacetate in the ketogenesis pathway.
  • Initially, two acetyl-CoA molecules condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA. (Option C)
  • Acetoacetyl-CoA then reacts with a third acetyl-CoA to form HMG-CoA, catalysed by HMG-CoA synthase.
  • Finally, HMG-CoA lyase cleaves HMG-CoA into acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA.
  • Acetoacetate may be reduced to β-hydroxybutyrate or decarboxylated to acetone.

Explanation of other options:

Mevalonate (Option A): Intermediate in the cholesterol synthesis pathway, not involved in ketogenesis.

5-Hydroxybutyryl-CoA (Option D): Not involved in the classical ketone body formation pathway.

questions.text: In a well-fed state, acetyl-CoA obtained from the diet is least used in the synthesis of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the well-fed state, excess acetyl-CoA is mainly utilised for fatty acid synthesis (Palmitoyl CoA) and TCA cycle activity (Citrate, Oxalosuccinate are intermediates).
  • However, Acetoacetate is a ketone body, which is not synthesised in the well-fed state. Instead, it is produced during prolonged fasting or starvation, when fatty acids are oxidised for energy.
  • Hence, in the well-fed state, acetyl-CoA is least used for acetoacetate synthesis.

Explanation of other options:

Palmitoyl CoA (Option A): Acetyl-CoA serves as the starting substrate for fatty acid synthesis in the well-fed state.

Citrate (Option B): Formed from acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate in the TCA cycle; also used for cytosolic acetyl-CoA transport for lipogenesis.

Oxalosuccinate (Option D): An intermediate in the TCA cycle, derived from isocitrate by isocitrate dehydrogenase.

questions.text: All of the following statements about lipoprotein lipase are true, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Unlike the other listed statements, Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) does require Apolipoprotein C-II (Apo C-II) as a cofactor for activation.
  • Its deficiency leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, marked by hypertriglyceridemia. (Option C).
  • Lipoprotein lipase is located on the walls of blood capillaries, anchored to the endothelium by negatively charged proteoglycan chains of heparan sulfate.
  • It has been found in the heart, adipose tissue, spleen, lung, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, and lactating mammary gland, although it is not active in adult liver. (Option A and B)
  • It is not normally found in blood; however, following injection of heparin, lipoprotein lipase is released from its heparan sulfate binding sites into the circulation.

questions.text: All of the following statements about apoproteins are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Apoprotein A-II and apo C-III inhibit lipoprotein lipase
  • Apoprotein C-II activates lipoprotein lipase (Option D)

Apolipoproteins carry out several roles:

  • They can form part of the structure of the lipoprotein, for example, apo B.
  • They are:
    • Enzyme cofactors, for example, C-II for lipoprotein lipase, A-I for lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) (Option A).
    • Enzyme inhibitors, for example, apo A-II and apo C-III for lipoprotein lipase, apo C-I for cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) (Option B).
    • They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B-100 and apo E for the LDL receptor, apo E for the LDL-receptor-related protein-1 (LRP-1), which has been identified as the remnant receptor, and apo A-I for the HDL receptor.
  • The functions of apo A-IV and apo D, however, are not yet clearly defined, although apo D is believed to be an important factor in human neurodegenerative disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following types of Hypertriglyceridemia is associated with an increase in chylomicron and VLDL remnants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (also known as familial dysbetalipoproteinemia or broad beta disease) is due to a defect in the clearance of chylomicron and VLDL remnants from plasma.
  • This is caused by a mutation in Apolipoprotein E, where patients possess only apo E2 isoforms, which have reduced binding to the hepatic apo-E receptor.
  • This results in the accumulation of remnant lipoproteins rich in cholesterol and triglycerides.

Explanation of other options:

Type I (Option A): Caused by lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II deficiency; characterised by elevated chylomicrons.

Type IIa (Option B): Characterised by elevated LDL levels due to LDL receptor deficiency, no increase in remnants.

Type IV (Option D): Involves increased VLDL levels, but remnant accumulation is not a feature.

questions.text: Increase Lipoprotein x is found in which type of disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lipoprotein X is an abnormal lipoprotein that appears in the plasma primarily in cholestasis.
  • In cholestasis, cholesterol is retained and combines with phospholipids and albumin to form Lipoprotein X (Lp-X).
  • Lp-X consists of free cholesterol, phospholipids, and minimal triglycerides, and lacks apolipoprotein B-100.
  • It is not normally found in plasma but appears in obstructive liver diseases.
  • This abnormal lipoprotein can deposit in skin folds, causing xanthomas, particularly xanthomata striata palmaris and plantar xanthomas.

Explanation of other options:

Atherosclerosis (Option A): Associated with increased LDL and VLDL.

Hepatitis (Option C): Can alter liver enzymes and lipid metabolism, but does not typically result in Lp-X formation.

Myocardial Infarction (Option D): May show elevated LDL or lipoprotein(a), but not Lp-X.

questions.text: A person on a fat-free, carbohydrate-rich diet continues to grow obese. Which of the following lipoproteins is likely to be elevated in his blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a fat-free but carbohydrate-rich diet, de novo lipogenesis becomes active in the liver.
  • Excess carbohydrates are converted to fatty acids via acetyl-CoA, which are then esterified to form triacylglycerol (TAG).
  • The liver packages this newly synthesised TAG into VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoproteins) and secretes them into the blood.
  • Hence, VLDL levels rise despite the diet being fat-free.
  • VLDL carries endogenously synthesised triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues.
  • Factors that enhance both the synthesis of triacylglycerol and the secretion of VLDL by the liver include
    • The fed state rather than the starved state;
    • The feeding of diets high in carbohydrate (particularly if they contain sucrose or fructose), leading to high rates of lipogenesis and esterification of fatty acids;
    • High levels of circulating FFA.
    • Ingestion of ethanol.
    • The presence of high concentrations of insulin and low concentrations of glucagon enhances fatty acid synthesis and esterification and inhibits their oxidation.

Explanation of other options:

Chylomicrons (Option A): Transport dietary triglycerides and cholesterol from the intestine; would not be elevated in a fat-free diet.

LDL (Option C): Derived from VLDL catabolism; its elevation is secondary and not the primary marker here.

HDL (Option D): Involved in reverse cholesterol transport; its levels are not typically elevated in this metabolic context.

Explanation:

  • Lipoprotein(a) is structurally similar to LDL, but with an additional apolipoprotein(a)
  • Apo(a) has significant structural homology with plasminogen, a key protein involved in fibrinolysis.
  • Apo(a) interferes with the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis.
  • This promotes clot stability and increases the risk of atherosclerosis and myocardial infarction.
  • Lp(a) is cleared mainly by the liver and is linked to intravascular thrombosis.

Explanation of other options:

Plasmin (Option B): Active form of plasminogen; no structural similarity to Lp(a).

Thrombin (Option C): Involved in coagulation (not fibrinolysis); no relation to Lp(a).

Prothrombin (Option D): Precursor to thrombin; unrelated to lipoprotein(a) structure.

questions.text: Both Triglycerides and HDL are increased in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Alcohol intake raises both serum triglycerides and HDL.
  • Alcoholic fatty liver is the first stage in alcoholic liver disease (ALD), which is caused by chronic alcohol intake and can progress to cirrhosis.
  • Ethanol metabolism increases NADH production via alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase.
  • The increased [NADH]/[NAD⁺] ratio inhibits β-oxidation of fatty acids and promotes lipogenesis.
  • This results in triglyceride accumulation in the liver and increases VLDL secretion.
  • Chronic alcohol consumption is also associated with elevated HDL levels due to increased hepatic production of apolipoproteins involved in HDL metabolism.

Explanation of other options:

Smoking (Option A): Smoking is associated with reduced HDL and increased oxidative stress but does not cause triglyceride elevation.

Athletes (Option B): Regular exercise in athletes raises HDL but usually reduces triglycerides due to enhanced lipid utilisation.

Statins (Option C: Statins reduce LDL and triglycerides and slightly increase HDL. They do not increase both HDL and triglycerides simultaneously.

choices.text: Used in the synthesis of chylomicron
It is directly used by tissues for energy needs
It is formed due to the increased activity of hormone-sensitive lipase
It is formed by the increased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase

questions.text: In prolonged fasting, Glycerol is formed from triglycerides. Which of the following statements is true regarding Glycerol:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During fasting, hormone-sensitive lipase is activated by decreased insulin and increased catecholamines, which promotes lipolysis in adipose tissue.
  • This enzyme catalyses the breakdown of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids (FFA) and glycerol.
  • The glycerol thus formed enters the liver, where it can be converted to glycerol-3-phosphate via glycerol kinase, and subsequently used for gluconeogenesis or triglyceride resynthesis.
  • Adipose tissue lacks glycerol kinase, so glycerol cannot be reused locally and must be transported to the liver.

Explanation of other options:

Used in the synthesis of chylomicrons (Option A): Chylomicrons are synthesised in the intestinal mucosa using dietary fat. Glycerol from adipose lipolysis is not involved in their synthesis.

It is directly used by tissues for energy needs (Option B): Tissues do not directly oxidise glycerol for energy. Instead, it is transported to the liver for gluconeogenesis or triglyceride synthesis.

It is formed by the increased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase (Option D): Lipoprotein lipase acts on circulating lipoproteins like chylomicrons and VLDL, not on intracellular triglycerides. It is not responsible for glycerol release during fasting.

questions.text: All of the following hormones promote lipolysis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lipolysis is stimulated by a variety of hormones that act via cAMP or other second messengers to activate hormone-sensitive lipase, which breaks down stored triglycerides.
  • These include norepinephrine, ACTH, glucagon, MSH, TSH, GH, and vasopressin. (Options A, B and C)
  • These hormones act by increasing intracellular cAMP or Ca²+, activating protein kinase A, which phosphorylates and activates hormone-sensitive lipase.
  • Insulin, in contrast, inhibits lipolysis by activating phosphodiesterase, which degrades cAMP, thereby inactivating hormone-sensitive lipase. It also promotes triglyceride synthesis and fat storage.
